reviewText: What happened to Solomon was terrible! This film gives you an idea of what he went through with a PG sensibility. This film is about a free man and his experience as a  slave. reviewText: There are two aspects of this film that make it endless. One is the endless suffering of literally millions (there are more than 20 million slaves in the world today) as seen through the life of Solomon Northrup. An upstanding, respected musician in the northeast, he is kidnapped and repeatedly sold in the south, where he endures inhumane barbarity that gets worse with every "master". These totally amoral "Christians" will turn your stomach as they beat and abuse and kill other humans at will.The other endless aspect is the film itself. It goes on far too long, due in major part to endless pointless closeups of Northrup, staring off, staring into the camera, trying not to emote, observing as a powerless bystander, witness, or even participant. There must be five full minutes if him just staring.Unfortunately, because of the subject matter, this film is a must-see. Sitting through it is a trial in itself.David Wineberg

reviewText: Black Girl, Killer of Sheep, 12 Years A Slave: I've seen two classics of Black World Cinema recently, Sembene' s Black Girl (1966) and Burnett's Killer of Sheep(1979). They are both about the loss of identity in various forms of work, in various social systems, and both feature music as a safe haven, a school, a church, a museum, a communal refuge from our worldly masters. So when I saw 12 Years a Slave it was all very familiar---loss of identity narrative, song as surrender, as soul-elevating refuge/respite from this weary world. All three films work by stripping (sometimes literally) the main character of his/her singularity . All three films feature a character who longs to distinguish him or herself who longs to establish a separate identity, a private dignity, but all three films show the community to be larger than any single member, and all three films show that its the community that carries the individual and gives each life it's meaning, its "individual" worth. So all three films work against the notion of individual expression, against the notion of ego, of hubris. And one imagines while watching each of these three films that the person each of these artists/directors has in mind while telling their respective stories is themselves. Each director has his/her distinct style but each of these directors places that "individual" style in the service of a larger, communal truth, and the larger community and truth in each of these films is not a black or a white community or truth but a human community and a human truth. All three films show art (cinema and song) to be the school, the church, the museum where whatever is not right in this world can be presented in a way that sustains the weary and condemns whatever it is in this life that makes us so.
summary: 12 Years a Slave in the context of Black World Cinema

reviewText: I read Solomon Northups' book two years ago and was ecstatic when I saw that a movie had been made last year. I saw the 2013 version this year and was really disappointed. I enjoyed this film more because it helped to open up what Solomon was mentally going through in his years as a slave.

reviewText: Gives a really good picture of the inequities of life as a slave, without an excessive amount of violence, making it suitable for older children. Should be a must see for teenagers to show the effect of lack of freedom has on social structure as well as the potential for abuse of the people under control. Reading reviews of the Soloman Northrup, they showed the massive whipping scars on his back, which fortunately was not shown graphically, although alluded to. The best documentary of slavery in the US I have seen or read.

reviewText: Difficult to watch but necessary that we learn it.I didn't know this older version existed until I searched amazon.com to pre-order the current version. Yell at the movie. Cry at the tragedy and injustice. But learn it.

I saw the movie (I think it was a 2004 or 20008?), and it was very true to this book.  I haven't seen the 2013 movie yet, but I look forward to seeing how it compares with the previous one.

reviewText: Foolish me, I was so excited to purchase this movie, because of all the Oscar buzz.  After the first few moments, I thought "holy cow, they're talking Oscars??  Seriously?? Are we really so guilt-ridden as a society to award Oscars to this drek? "  So I kept watching, although the picture was blurry, the stages cheesy, the acting wooden, the transitions choppy, and the dialog nearly laughable.  It comes across as an 8th grade play.  And the background music took me back to the melodramatic scores we used to hear in those 1950's movies, where violins telegraphed the heightened tension we were supposed to feel.  I sat through the entire movie, because I wanted to see poor Solomon freed.  In a completely lame and anticlimactic ending, he does go home.  Only later, Incredulous that anyone would consider an award for this film, I read other reviews and realized that this 1980's made-for-tv flick has the SAME NAME as the 2013 version.  I feel a bit duped, and would advise others to wait for the current film's release to rent it.  Audience tastes have matured significantly since this version was made and I believe most people would be as disappointed as I was.

Then a white slave auctioneer, came into the barn and began beating him.  Bad movie, in my opinion, but great history in the "special features".

reviewText: This movie production of a book I read is a winner in many ways.  It takes you from freedom, to a slave pen, to a plantation where you are another man's property, bought and paid for to do the bidding of your new master.The one fault in the movie could be the acting itself, which comes across as a bit stiff at times. But the true story and its subject of American slavery are so captivating that the players on screen become convincing symbols of the many injustices suffered by Blacks during the era. The suffering voices of the enslaved definitely come through.Every black character carries the scars of slavery in one way or another.  The one black man in their midst who'd been intimate with freedom before being tricked and kidnapped into slavery, Solomon Northrup, becomes well acquainted with those scars and ongoing fears.  How does a proud and dignified man survive 12 years in a cruel, undignified, humiliating environment?  Allow yourself to be transported to America's 1840's deep south as an enslaved northerner with an education and middleclass refinement.  It is this movie and Solomon Northrup that brings you closest to being able to say, I've walked in the shoes of a slave.
summary: To Steal, Sell and Subjugate To Slavery
